title: Understanding Vulvar Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Vulvar cancer is a type of cancer that develops on the external female genital area (the vulva), including the labia, clitoris, and skin around the vaginal opening. Although relatively rare, understanding it helps with **early detection** and **prevention**.

content.description: Quick Facts: Vulvar cancer is most common in women over 60 and is often linked to HPV or chronic skin conditions. Early detection improves outcomes. Symptoms may include itching, lumps, or noticeable skin changes.

content.value: Vulvar cancer usually begins in the skin cells of the vulva. Understanding where it starts helps doctors determine the best treatment and predict how the disease may behave.

items.title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
items.description: The most common type — 85–90% of vulvar cancers. It begins in the thin, flat cells on the surface of the vulva.

items.title: Melanoma of the Vulva
items.description: A less common type of vulvar cancer, which can behave more aggressively, begins in the pigment-producing cells of the vulva.

items.title: Pre-Cancerous Changes (VIN)
items.description: Some cases begin as VIN – Vulvar Intraepithelial Neoplasia, where abnormal cells appear before developing into cancer.

content.title: Did You Know?
content.description: Detecting VIN early and treating it promptly can reduce the risk of it developing into vulvar cancer.

content.value: Not everyone with these risk factors will develop vulvar cancer, but they increase likelihood.

steps: HPV Infection (High-Risk Strains) — High-risk HPV types, particularly HPV 16, significantly increase vulvar cancer risk
Older Age (Most Common After 60) — Vulvar cancer is more common in women over 60
Smoking — Smoking weakens the immune system and increases HPV persistence
Long-Term Skin Conditions (e.g., Lichen Sclerosus) — Chronic inflammatory vulvar skin disorders increase risk
Weakened Immune System — A weak immune system reduces the body's ability to repair abnormal cells
History of Cervical or Vaginal Pre-cancers — Conditions like CIN or VAIN raise the risk of similar changes on the vulva

content.title: Good to Know
content.description: Having one or more risk factors does not mean you will get vulvar cancer — but understanding them helps with early detection and prevention.

content.value: Early vulvar cancer may not have obvious symptoms. As it progresses, watch for these warning signs:

items: A cut or sore that won't heal
A lump or mass on the vulva
Changes in a mole or birthmark

content.title: Warning
content.description: If you notice any of these symptoms, see your doctor promptly. Early detection significantly improves treatment outcomes.

content.value: If vulvar cancer is suspected, your doctor will perform tests to confirm the diagnosis.

steps: Vulvar Examination - Your doctor examines the vulva and may also check the groin area (lymph nodes) for any swelling or abnormalities. A general pelvic exam may be done if needed.
Biopsy - A small sample of tissue is taken from the affected area of the vulva and sent to a laboratory. This is the only way to confirm whether cancer cells are present.
Vulvoscopy (sometimes called colposcopy of the vulva) - A magnifying device may be used to examine the skin of the vulva more closely and guide where to take a biopsy.

content.title: Purpose
content.description: These tests help determine the stage and spread of cancer to guide treatment planning.

content.value: Treatment depends on the stage, size, and spread of cancer. Surgery is the most common treatment.

content.title: Surgery
content.description: Surgery aims to remove the cancer while preserving as much healthy tissue as possible.

items.title: Wide local excision
items.description: Removal of the cancer with a margin of healthy tissue

items.title: More extensive vulvar surgery
items.description: May be needed for larger or deeper cancers

items.title: Lymph node assessment
items.description: Lymph nodes in the groin may be checked or removed to see if the cancer has spread

items.title: Radiation Therapy
items.description: May be given after surgery or sometimes instead of surgery

items.title: Chemoradiation
items.description: Chemotherapy given together with radiotherapy in certain cases

items.title: Chemotherapy alone
items.description: Occasionally used for advanced or recurrent disease

content.title: Enhanced Recovery
content.description: After surgery, patients receive enhanced recovery support to aid healing and return to normal activities.

content.value: Simple steps can help reduce risk and support early detection.

content.title: Why Prevention Matters
content.description: Vulvar cancer is uncommon, but awareness of symptoms and risk factors can help identify changes early, when treatment is more effective.

items.text: Seeking medical advice for long-term vulvar skin conditions (such as lichen sclerosus)
Being aware of any persistent changes to the vulvar skin
Practicing safer sex to reduce HPV exposure
Early detection is linked with better treatment outcomes
Regular check-ups are important if you have symptoms or ongoing vulvar skin conditions
HPV vaccination helps protect against HPV-related vulvar disease
Any long-lasting vulvar change (itching, lump, sore, colour change) should be reviewed

content.title: Key Takeaway
content.description: Staying aware of symptoms, managing skin conditions, and protecting against HPV are important steps in maintaining vulvar health and detecting problems early.

content.value: Important points to remember about Vulvar Cancer

content.title: What You Should Know
content.description: Vulvar cancer is rare but serious. Early diagnosis is linked with better outcomes, which is why understanding symptoms and being aware of changes is important.

items.text: Early detection is associated with more effective treatment
Persistent itching, lumps, sores, or skin changes should be checked
Medical review is important if you have ongoing symptoms or vulvar skin conditions
HPV vaccination helps reduce the risk of HPV-related vulvar disease
Being aware of changes to your vulvar skin supports early detection

content.title: Final Message
content.description: Staying aware, seeking medical advice for persistent symptoms, and protecting against HPV can make a real difference in maintaining your health.
